description.narrative: The Child Protection Fund’s goal is to realize the basic rights of the most vulnerable children in Zimbabwe through provision of critical child protection interventions within a child and HIV-sensitive social protection framework. It builds on the CPF Phase I & II, adopting a multi-dimensional poverty approach to child vulnerability which simultaneously addresses household poverty, gender disparities, disability, HIV and risk of violence, exploitation and abuse. Through a theory of change, the programme aims to ensure that “children, families and communities access improved preventive and responsive child protection services reinforced by household and community economic resilience in targeted areas.” (See also theory of change attached in track). The CPF outcomes are: - increased availability and accessibility of age/gender-appropriate, affordable, and well-coordinated Child Protection services in targeted areas (18 districts). - families and communities in targeted areas have information, knowledge and skills on violence against children and how to protect children improved evidence-based policies and legislative instruments to address violence against children implemented and reinforced by institutional capacity.

The Child Protection Fund’s goal is to realize the basic rights of the most vulnerable children in Zimbabwe through provision of critical child protection interventions within a child and HIV-sensitive social protection framework. It builds on the CPF Phase I (2011-2016), adopting a multi-dimensional approach to child vulnerability which simultaneously addresses household poverty, gender disparities, disability, HIV and risk of violence, exploitation and abuse. Taking lessons from CPF I and II, this third phase of CPF has a stronger focus on violence reduction through prevention, information management and governance structures and capacity. The third phase does not include cash transfer.Through a theory of change developed for CPF III, the programme aims to ensure that “children, families and communities access improved preventive and responsive child protection services reinforced by household and community economic resilience in targeted areas.”
An increasing body of evidence about violence against children in Zimbabwe shows that violence is widespread and cuts across age, gender, and socio-economic status. There are many interlinked causes that include: family dislocation and an absence of positive parenting due to temporary migration; a high caseload of single and double orphans which is a legacy of the HIV pandemic; a propensity for resolving disputes violently that stems from generally high levels of trauma and stress in the country; overcrowded living conditions and high dependency ratios due to poverty and jobless-ness; children witnessing sexual relations from a very young age; and widespread unhealthy adolescent relationships in which negative coping strategies such as transactional sex are common, and in which regressive gender norms mixed with substance abuse generate high levels of intimate partner violence.
This project is co-funded with the Swiss Development Cooperation (SDC) and DFID.

Våld mot flickor och pojkar är ett utbrett problem i Zimbabwe som har förvärrats ytterligare av den ekonomiska krisen samt utbredd torka. De senaste årens utmaningar har ökat hushållens sårbarhet, lett till att sociala strukturer brutits ner, samt ökat risken för att kvinnor och barn utsätts för könsrelaterat våld både inom och utanför hemmet (såsom sexuellt våld, våld i hemmet, tvångsäktenskap, barnäktenskap, psykosocialt och emotionellt våld). Barn lider även av att ökat antal blir föräldralösa då föräldrar tvingas lämna hemmet för att söka försörjning på annan ort eller annat land, vidare brister statens förmåga att tillgodose barnrättigheter på många övriga punkter. En av tre unga flickor i Zimbabwe utsätts för sexuella övergrepp innan de fyller 16 år. Statistik för antalet pojkar som utsätts för övergrepp finns inte då det anses för skamligt för att prata om eller rapportera. Zimbabwe har även bland de högsta siffrorna vad gäller barnäktenskap och könsrelaterat våld i Södra Afrika (mer information finns att hitta i Global Gender Gap Report och i Girls Not Brides Report).
UNICEF har ansökt om finansiering på 60 miljoner kronor för stöd till sitt landprogram avseende de tematiska områdena Barns Skydd och Socialt Inkluderande mellan 2018 och 2021, (det sk Child Protection Fund CPF). Sverige har goda erfarenheter av tidigare stöd till UNICEFs barnrättsarbete i Zimbabwe. Samarbetspartnern, UNICEF, är ett FN-organ och därmed en juridisk enhet som kan ingå avtal med Sida. Parterna i avtalet, Sverige, genom Sida, och UNICEF i Zimbabwe använder för ändamålet framförhandlade avtalsmallar mellan Sida och UNICEF för att ingå ett bilateralt avtal om tematisk finansiering. DFID och Swiss Development Cooperation, de övriga givare som stödjer detta program, kommer fortsätta sitt stöd. Alla tre givarna samarbetar vad gäller uppföljning och dialog-frågor runt programmet, genom möten med UNICEF och gemensamma fältresor. DFID står för ca 50% av total budget, SDC för 30% och Sverige övriga 20% (budgeten bifogas)
De föreslagna interventionerna ska säkerställa att a) ålders- och könsanpassad service för barns skydd finns tillgänglig, och att b) samhällen och familjer i de utvalda områdena har kunskap och färdigheter för att skydda sina barn. UNICEF Zimbabwe arbetar med en rad partner för att genomföra landprogrammet, inklusive internationella, nationella och lokala icke-statliga organisationer, organisationer i det civila samhället, statliga strukturer, samhällsbaserade organisationer och olika intressegrupper. Landskontoret har ansvaret för planering, genomförande, ekonomisk förvaltning (inklusive för implementerande parter), kvalitetssäkring och övervakning av landprogrammet och därmed de svenska medel. Programsamarbetsavtal (PCA) är undertecknade mellan UNICEF i Zimbabwe och de olika implementeringspartnerna och tjänsteleverantörerna enligt behov under hela genomförandet av landprogrammet. Upphandling av konsulter och inköp av olika produkter görs i enlighet med sk HACT-regler. (mer information finns i Sida’s centrala organisationsbedömning av UNICEF). UNICEF vidareförmedlar medel till en rad civilsamhällesorganisationer men ger inget direkt budget stöd till regeringen.

description.narrative: Overall the CPF seems to be progressing well, even through the current context of Covid-19 The programme quickly adapted to the circumstances. The CPF is progressing in relation to original project proposal. However, some changes were made in the light of Covid-19 as indicated in the attached work plan for 2020. UNICEF did not request additionally funding for the COVID responds, but reprogrammed some of their funding, also Difd provide emergency funding for Child Protection and Sida HQ might provide emergency funding through global mechanisms (check with Sida HQ HUM). During the period under review, the National Case Management System served a total of 75,320 children (31,895 and 43,425) with child protection services including access to justice and critical child protection in emergency (CPiE) services in the 18 CPF supported districts. The NCMS continues to rely on a trained cadre of volunteer Community Childcare Workers (CCWs) supervised by Government social workers for the identification and initial referral of cases. The CPF II intensified implementation of prevention strategies: early detection/interventions and addressing social norms and harmful practices that perpetuate violence against children through a comprehensive parenting programme and reached 34,511 families with parenting skills. Additionally, 15,438 adolescents were trained in assertiveness building and skills to say no to violence and seek help. The HSCT delivered regular social transfers up to June 2019 and reached 28,663 households. Payments were paused after monetary policy changes which saw the reintroduction of the local currency and termination of the multi-currency system. The pausing of payments was a risk management measure. Payments will be completed in the 4 outstanding districts by the end of the second quarter of 2020. There was progress on policy and legal reform work with a number of child protection-related policies and Bills now at different stages of development and finalisation. With technical and financial support from UNICEF, bills and policies went through various stages of consultations. Notable progress made on the Child Justice Bill, Disability policy and Bill, and Marriages Bill amongst others. UNICEF also supported the MOPSLSW with its Strategic Planning process. Several important studies, research and reviews were successfully completed in 2019. They include the HSCT Endline Impact Evaluation, HSCT Qualitative Study, Adolescents Intimate Partner Violence, Results-Based Financing and Life Experiences of Adolescents. The plan for 2020 is to disseminate the findings and to influence policy and programme implementation. This output supports the creation of safe environments for the protection of children from violence, abuse and exploitation. The activities supported were positive parenting training and engagement of girls and boys (11-17 years) in Champions of Child Protection (CoCP) groups, and peer to peer support groups. The headline results achieved in 2019 include: 15,438 adolescents (5, 348 boys & 10,090 girls) were trained in assertiveness building and received protection information including preventing child marriage. 76% girls and 79% boys in the target group in selected districts reported to be knowledgeable on protection risks and how to report child protection violations.? The Champions of Child Protection (CoCP) implemented by Plan International improved knowledge on VAC identification and reporting. Childline piloted a new and innovative peer to peer support group model. The intervention involves face to face interactions and virtual discussions using social media platforms such as WhatsApp groups. The groups are facilitated by trained peer leaders and discuss child protection issues. The Peer to Peer support groups were introduced following a 2017 needs assessment which showed that adolescents have resorted to peer support as the traditional family systems weaken or become non-existent. Direct beneficiary feedback from parents and caregivers who were trained in positive parenting sessions suggested the initiative had positive effects on positive discipline approaches, promoted positive parent child communication, increased knowledge of child development. The HSCT delivered cash to households regularly and predictably until June 2019. At this stage 28,663 food-poor and labour-constrained households were reached with cash. Evidence generated in 2019 from the HSCT end line impact evaluation shows that the HSCT empowered vulnerable households by increasing their purchases of food and other consumption items, improved dietary diversity and increased access to basic social services. Additionally, there were other positive programme effects on purchase of productive assets and small livestock, and reduction in negative coping mechanisms by households when faced with risks and shocks. The Government of Zimbabwe through the Reserve Bank issued Statutory Instrument 142 of 2019 which outlawed the use of the multi-currency system in favour of a return of the Zimbabwe Dollar. There was uncertainty and lack of clarity on SI 142 and the associated Exchange Control Directive RU102/2019. As a risk management measure, UNICEF paused HSCT payments in four remaining districts: Buhera, Zvimba, Mwenezi and Mudzi. The reintroduction of the Zimbabwe dollar had implications for the remaining HSCT payments. For example, the contract with HSCT payment delivery agency, was in US dollars. Similarly, the Bank Guarantee was also in US dollars. After it became clear that the remaining HSCT payments have to be done in the local currency, UNICEF took steps to change the contract to ZWL currency, and to seek assistance from the RBZ for cash availability. The negotiations with RBZ and the Bank, held at the highest levels between the UNICEF Representative and the Governor of the RBZ, took longer than expected and cash was only made available in February 2020. The Ministry and Securico have also had to convert pay sheets to Zimbabwe dollars. Preparations are underway to clear the payments in the four outstanding districts by June 2020.
